Award.AwardTitle: Biology, Analysis, Geometry, Energies, Links: A Program on Low-dimensional Topology, Geometry, and Applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides partial funding for a two-week program "Biology, Analysis, Geometry, Energies, Links" that will take place during June 17 - 28, 2019 at the Institute of Mathematics and its Applications in Minneapolis, MN. The goals of this program are twofold. On the one hand, it is focused on interdisciplinarity, bringing different scientific groups together whose research areas are adjacent but would benefit from closer collaborations. On the other hand, this program aims at bridging gaps between different stages of scientific development: namely undergraduate study, graduate work, and postdoctoral research. The first week is a summer school targeted at graduate students and early career researchers. This is followed by a workshop that builds on the topics covered in the prior week and features speakers from a broad set of disciplines such as mathematical physics, topology, approximation theory, analysis, and microbiology.


Low-dimensional topology, geometry and knot theory are excellent platforms for collaboration and training: they are highly interdisciplinary, and have features that are accessible to a beginner, while at the same time connecting to the deepest and most advanced realms of mathematics, biology, and physics. The summer school presents a state-of-the-art introduction to several mathematical fields concerned with curves, surfaces, and higher-dimensional analogs. The workshop will present the latest developments in the fields discussed at the summer school and beyond. Topics to be explored include nonlinear mechanics, topological fluid dynamics, low-dimensional topology, quantum invariants, homology theory, categorification, contact geometry, geometric curvature energies, discretization of geometric flows, and discrete differential geometry. More information about the event is at : https://www.ima.umn.edu/2018-2019/SW6.17-28.19

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The two week program “Biology, Analysis, Geometry, Energies, Links” on low-dimensional topology, geometry, and applications was held June 17-28, 2019 at the Institute for Mathematics and its Applications of the University of Minnesota, Minneapolis, MN.

The program was divided in two events. The first week was a summer school for graduate students and early career researchers with an emphasis on the interplay of low-dimensional topology, geometry and knot theory, and their applications to other disciplines. The second week was a workshop that built on the topics covered in the prior week and featured speakers from a broad set of disciplines with connections to low-dimensional topology, geometry and knots.

 

During the summer school in the first week, Professors Jun O’Hara (Chiba University), Peter Schroeder (California Institute of Technology), Jennifer Schultens (University of California, Davis), and Gert van der Heijden (Imperial College London) each gave four 1 hour lectures in their area of expertise: respectively, knot energies, discrete differential geometry, 3-dimensional manifolds, and non-linear mechanics of elastic structures. These introductory courses were designed to be accessible to the 26 (CHECK!) young mathematicians (under-graduate, graduate and post-docs) attending the summer school. (Also 9 women CHECK!). On the first day, the summer school participants were split into 4 tutorial groups, one for each speaker according to their research interests. Each group then worked for 8 hours over the week (1 or 2 hours each day) on open research problems. In the morning of Saturday June 22, the students presented the work they had been doing over the week. In this way, the participants were able to learn about and experience different active research areas of this interdisciplinary field. Researchers at all levels were able to interact through the many lectures, discussions, and the exercise tutorials.

Also during the first week, Emeritus Professor Ken Millett (University of California, Santa Barbara) gave three 1 hour lectures on knotting and linking in biology. In the second week, Professor Millett gave a highly successful public lecture “Very Tiny Knots in Nature: an introduction to molecular biology mysteries”. About 100 people attended this talk.


In the second week, the workshop built on the topics covered in the first week and featured speakers from a broad set of disciplines with connections to low-dimensional topology, geometry and knots. Some of the themes of the workshop included: talks on knots in biology and polymers, knot energies with applications to DNA and supercoiling, knotting probability, folding pathways for knots, physical knot theory with applications to a tokamak fusion reactor. The goal of the second week was to bring together leading experts in various theoretical and applied aspects of low-dimensional topology, to promote and enhance unifying techniques, exchange and explore ideas, to establish new connections, to foster new collaborations, and still to provide training for students and junior researchers. There were 20 speakers. Seven speakers were students, postdocs, or junior researchers. A third of the speakers were women. A Poster Session with about 18 (CHECK!) posters gave more young participants a platform to present their recent research results to a broad audience. The researchers interacted through lectures and discussions and new collaborations were established among the participants during the conference.


The conference webpage was created at
https://www.ima.umn.edu/2018-2019/SW6.17-28.19
It contains the full program, titles, abstracts and also publicly accessible videos of most talks.

In summary, the summer school and workshop provided an amazing opportunity to train to students and postdocs in active research areas connecting low dimensional topology, geometry, knots and applications, gave the speakers a platform to present their recent research results, and fostered new collaborations among all the participants.
